ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Right cerebellar medulloblastoma
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Confirmed by CT scan showing a large mass in the right posterior fossa with hydrocephalus.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Central Auditory Processing Disorder (secondary)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Indicated by poor frequency pattern test performance, attributed to hydrocephalus affecting cerebral structures.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To investigate neurological symptoms (headache, vomiting, imbalance) and visualize intracranial structures.
To assess the integrity of the auditory brainstem pathways.
To evaluate central auditory processing and pattern perception.
To assess binaural interaction at the brainstem level.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The patient presents with a confirmed right cerebellar medulloblastoma and hydrocephalus. Peripheral hearing sensitivity and speech recognition are normal bilaterally. The ABR shows only a subtle prolongation of the I-III interval on the right, consistent with the extra-axial location of the tumor distant from the brainstem. However, central auditory processing is significantly impaired, as evidenced by poor bilateral performance on the frequency pattern test, likely due to the effects of hydrocephalus on cerebral auditory structures.

tests.name: Computed tomography (CT) scans
tests.result_summary: Large mass lesion in the right posterior fossa (cerebellum) with fourth ventricle compression and associated hydrocephalus.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal hearing sensitivity bilaterally; thresholds 0-10 dB HL.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Excellent word recognition scores: Right 96%, Left 92%.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Subtle abnormality on the right with I-III interval of 2.48 msec; left ear normal.

proposed_items: No audiological intervention (e.g., hearing aids) required as peripheral hearing is normal
Continue medical management with Neurology-Neurosurgery for tumor and hydrocephalus
counseling_actions: Explain that basic hearing sensitivity is normal
Discuss how the tumor location (cerebellum) primarily affects balance and coordination rather than direct hearing pathways
Explain that difficulty with complex sound patterns (frequency pattern test) is likely related to hydrocephalus affecting wider brain processing areas

red_flags_present: Right-sided headaches with nausea and vomiting
Imbalance and tendency to fall to the right

escalation.rationale_short: Patient has a confirmed brain tumor and hydrocephalus requiring neurosurgical management.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor auditory status if requested by Neurosurgery.
